{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3377205,"name":"Kade Rabe","username":"Kadd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kadd/{size}/178400_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-30T13:47:21.914Z","cooked":"

I’m wondering if anyone has data on the ratio of motors used at champs this year, I especially want to know about the teams who won their divisions, or had a strong run in general, which motors did they use? and possibly even why they chose them. Which motor seems to come out on top? if i get enough people’s data and there isn’t one already ill also make a spreadsheet.

This is reported to FMS in a way. So First has the data if they choose to publish it.

Just off the top of my head for Einstein:

254: all Krakens
1323: all Krakens
1690: Krakens only on drive, falcons everywhere else (at least when they revealed)
604: all krakens
9483: all falcons apparently had a couple neos too
1678: all krakens
4481: Neo/neo vortex (might be all vortex now?)
6328: Had both on the dev bot, Krakens on drive / steer and in some other places, but looking at their stuff now I think its almost all / all krakens (@davepowers correct me here)
2056: all krakens
2468: Vortexes and Neo 550s (might have a couple neos in there, not sure)

For other teams definitely look at behind the bumpers as they come out, I doubt FIRST will release this info to be honest

CTRE / Redux 775 size BLDC motor to compete with the Neo 550.

Redux showed theirs off at champs, CTRE likely working with WCP on this but it hasn’t been talked about publicly.

Exciting, I didn’t know these were already called out in FIRST-controlled code…

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":26,"updated_at":"2024-05-01T01:44:29.647Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":477,"readers_count":476,"score":100.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":464966,"topic_slug":"neos-vs-falcons-vs-krakens-at-champs","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":52319,"username":"CyberClone","name":"Vaughn Khouri","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/neos-vs-falcons-vs-krakens-at-champs/464966/13","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3377753,"name":"Vaughn Khouri","username":"CyberClone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberclone/{size}/229178_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-01T03:35:12.294Z","cooked":"

Haha I haven’t seen anything, only heard rumors. That being said, I feel one can kind of put 2 and 2 together:

  1. The Kraken is an incredibly powerful motor, but it’s also super large, heavy, and expensive. Though it’s an incredible product for the money, there are applications where a 775-class motor just makes more sense. One look at the pocketing on 1323s robot and you’ll see why they might want a lighter alternative…
  2. CTRE clearly likes their ecosystem, but V6 doesn’t support the brushed motor controllers at all. They’re apparently moving away from brushed motors, so they’ll want to have an equivalent replacement. This also makes a lot of sense when you consider SwerveXS, which is marketed as using a 775…but I really don’t think teams will want to do this because of the compatibility issues with CTRE swerve generator.
  3. Aside from being a clear open market segment, it’s also not really hard to compete (although redux could change this). The 550 has never really been ideal, ever since it was introduced:
  • Free speed way too high to be useable without a UP or VP
  • Tiny output shaft is really impractical
  • Will smoke itself if it stalls for more then a few seconds unless super conservative current limits are set (which they aren’t by default)
  • No integrated controller
  • Has to use a spark max, which is practically the size of the motor itself, and has to be placed nearby; which makes the whole package larger then a Neo or Kraken class motor anyway
  1. Redux just proved you can fit a 2 inch bolt circle and integrated controller nicely on a 775 size motor, which was one of the main feasibility concerns people had

So given this, I’d be really surprised if we don’t get a Kraken X30 type thing in the next year or two - and I’d bet on it being a huge success.

Now RC, if you’re reading this, hopefully I’m not completely wrong

CyberClone:

but it’s also super large, heavy

Calling a Kraken super large and heavy is wild when a CIM weighs more than twice a Kraken without a controller.

I’ve already bet on a new CTR/WCP 775 style motor for 2025. I just have to be patient and wait for it to be announced in the fall.

Calling a Kraken super large and heavy is wild when a CIM weighs more than twice a Kraken without a controller.

Man, sometimes I forget to appreciate how much we get with modern FRC and COTs

I wish we were on einstein but you are correct about vortex and neo550s. We had 4 neos as well (1 intake, 2 climb, 1 shooter pivot).

We only used neos because we had a lot of them in inventory already and because vortexes are expensive and were sold out. Having 3 teams means 3x the order QTY of parts which can be hard when things get backordered.
